column4: I was about to give up when I noticed that network manager was detecting the phone as a possible cellular connection: but it's grayed out and can't be accessed.
So the phone is detected by Ubuntu on some level, and it charges when plugged into the computer, but I can't interface with it as a user...
In the last month month and a variety of windows computer (maybe two or three) at internet cafes near my house...
No. It's an generic chinese phone. I think I said that as long as I've owned this phone, with this ubuntu install, I've never had problems.

But the system is acting a little funny. For example, one day I woke up and tried to access a folder throught the "Places" menu: everything in that menu now opens with VLC!!! I have no idea how to fix that either.

I don't know about the OS. I really don't know much about phones. It was bought in Asia, but as I said, I've never had any software issues or connection issues before and I've never used any software between the phone and computer at all. ever.
It's 11:30 pm here. I can't go buy additional hardware right now.
I really don't think it's hardware guys.
Hal is recognizing the mobile.
There's a screen shot of network manager identifying the phone on this thread: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1837199
Anything in dmesg?
type in dmesg once, then plug in the phone and do another dmesg and see the new lines
maybe we can find out if it uses mass storage or something else (mass storage would be a lot easier)
use a pastenbin site
There's nothing in the dmesg log, you will have to connect it for that
no, still here :), we need now a pastebin after you connected the phone
I don't see any USB connection notices
Is it USB?
That's odd - if NM finds it there must be something in dmesg
yes, that would be weird
that is some very odd problem you have - I never seen any USB device not detected in dmesg
um...
